questions.stem: All the following are diagnostic criteria for bacterial vaginosis EXCEPT:
options: Presence of erythema of the cervix.
Clue cells seen on vaginal saline preparation.
Characteristic fishy odor release with addition of KOH to vaginal secretion.

options: Gram stain is a very sensitive method of diagnosis.
The spirochete does not cross the placenta during pregnancy.
It affects sexually active, and non-sexually active individuals.

questions.stem: An 18-year-old G1P0 at 14weeks gestation is noted to have a positive RPR with a positive confirmatory TPH test. The patient states that she is allergic to penicillin, with swelling of the tongue and throat in the past. The most appropriate next step:
options: Pretreat with prednisone, antihistaminic then administer penicillin.
Pretreat with prednisone, then administer penicillin.

questions.stem: A 18-year-old woman complains of painful swelling of her left labium. She has been taking analgesics and using warm sitz baths. O/E a 6-cm swollen, red, tender, tense cystic mass in the base of the Lt labium majus is detected. Next step is:
options: Incision and drainage of the mass.

options: Is characterized by an offensive discharge and a strawberry cervix.
Dark ground microscopy readily identifies the clue cells.
Can be asymptomatic for several months after being acquired.
Management is usually with metronidazole and contact tracing.

questions.stem: What is the current first-line treatment for gonorrhea?
options: Azithromycin 1 g orally as a single dose.
Cefixime 400 mg orally three times daily for 14 days.
Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM as a single dose with azithromycin 1 g single oral dose.
Penicillin 1.2 g intramuscularly as a single dose.
Erythromycin 500 mg four times daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: A 21-year-old female attends clinic with a 3-day history of a single, painless, genital ulcer. She has just returned from backpacking around South East Asia, where she had two sexual partners. What is the most likely causative organism?

A 21-year-old patient is seen for a 2mm pigmented flat lesion with irregular margins on the left labia. The most appropriate next step:
A 63-year-old patient is seen for routine examination. An excoriated 2-cm lesion of 3 months duration is found on her Lt labium majus. Next best step is:
options: Paint the area with toluidine blue stain.

questions.stem: An antenatal patient tests positive for syphilis using VDRL screening test. Which of the following is a definitive test for syphilis?

The protective mechanisms against infection of the genital tract include:
options: The vagina is lined by keratinized squamous epithelium.
Alkaline vaginal PH caused by bacteria flora.
Progesterone promotes growth of vaginal epithelium.

questions.stem: Regarding candida infection, all the following are true EXCEPT:
options: Incidence is increased with the use of oral contraceptive pills.
Incidence is decreased with the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Is not the commonest cause of abnormal vaginal discharge in women of the child bearing age.

questions.stem: A 26-year-old newly married female attended with her husband due to severe dyspareunia and failed intercourse since their wedding. All of the following can contribute to this condition EXCEPT:
Gynecological causes of acute pelvic pain include:

A 29-year-old NG complains of grayish fishy vaginal discharge with no vulvar pruritis or burning. O/E, there is a thin discharge at the vaginal vault. The vaginal pH is 5.5. The cervix is not inflamed and there is no cervical discharge. The most likely diagnosis is:
The best treatment is:
options: Doxycycline 100 mg PO twice daily for 1 week.
Ampicillin 500 mg PO twice daily for 1 week.
Metronidazole 500 mg PO twice daily for 1 week.

questions.stem: If the above patient was pregnant 8 weeks, the treatment would be:

A 20-year-old G2P0 with a LMP 5 days ago, presents with severe pelvic pain, chills and fever. Pregnancy test is -ve. Urine analysis is normal. WBC is 18.000. Temp is 39.8. O/E, abdomen shows diffuse tenderness, rebound tenderness, with guarding. The most likely diagnosis is:
The most appropriate initial antibiotic regimen is:
options: Doxycycline 100 mg PO twice daily for 14 days.
Clindamycin 450 mg IV/8 hours + gentamycin 1 mg/kg every 12 hours.
Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM + doxycycline 100 mg PO twice daily for 14 days.
Cefoxitine 2 gm IV every 6 hours + doxycycline 100 mg twice daily.
Ofloxacin 400 mg + metronidazole 500 mg PO twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: Patient appears to be doing better. Then, suddenly the temperature became over 40°C and a rigid abdomen. PV reveals no pelvic mass. Most likely diagnosis is:
Your management should be:

A 24-year-old newly married female, complains of lower abdominal colicky pain, with dysuria and frequency. Her LMP was a week ago. She has no fever, no vaginal discharge. Her pelvic examination is normal, except of suprapubic tenderness. No masses or abnormal bleeding or discharge. Medical and surgical histories are irrelevant. What is your provisional diagnosis?
Your first recommended investigation is:
options: Vaginal swab for culture and sensitivity.

questions.stem: Four weeks later, she returns with excessive foul-smelling vaginal discharge, with mild irritation and superficial dyspareunia. Still no fever. your diagnosis is:
Your management will be:
options: Broad spectrum antibiotic twice daily for 2 weeks.

questions.stem: The patient returns a week later with no improvement; this is most probably due to:
options: The use of acidic vaginal douching.

questions.stem: Natural barriers against genital tract infections include all the following EXCEPT:
options: Stratified squamous epithelial lining of the vagina.

options: It is the most common viral STDs.

questions.stem: All the following about candida infection are correct EXCEPT:
options: The infection is common with pregnancy.
It is the second most common cause of vaginitis in the childbearing period.
Vaginal isoconazole or miconazole are effective.

questions.stem: Regarding TB of the female genital tract, choose the correct statement:
options: It is almost always Iry TB.
+ve tuberculin test is diagnostic of active disease.
Endometrium is the most common involved site in the genital tract.
Endometrial biopsy should be done in the post-menstrual period.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old P2 complains of intermenstrual bleeding. O/E: pelvis is firmly fixed. Endometrial biopsy shows 'giant cells, caseous necrosis, wz granuloma'. Most likely is:

Candida infection is commonly associated with all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Use of combined oral contraceptive pills.

questions.stem: Regarding diagnosis of acute PID (salpingitis), choose the correct statement:
options: History of recent delivery, abortion or instrumentation is common.
Pain is usually felt in the right more than the left iliac fossa.
Culture of the vaginal discharge is the gold standard in diagnosis.
Symptoms are usually mild with gonococcal infection.

questions.stem: The following are protective mechanisms against genital tract infection EXCEPT:
options: Squamous epithelium lining of the vagina.
Presence of humoral and cell mediated immunity.

questions.stem: A 16 years old girl, presented by an anterior midline cystic vulval swelling at the site of her circumcision. What is your first differential diagnosis?
A 32 years old sexually active woman presents with acute abdominal pain and offensive vaginal discharge. Her temperature is 38.5°. Most likely diagnosis is:

A 20-year-old college student presents with lower abdominal pain and fever. O/E, bilateral abdominal tenderness. PV shows tenderness with cervical mobilization. Her pregnant test is negative. Most likely diagnosis:

A 16-year-old sexually active nulliparous female complains of pelvic pain and vaginal discharge. O/E, her temp is 39.8, pain on moving cervix, and mass and tenderness in right adnexa. According to CDC, most appropriate treatment is:
options: Outpatient with penicillin IM, doxycycline oral for 14days and reexamine in 3days.
Outpatient with ceftriaxone IM, doxycycline bid/14days, reexamine in one week.
Outpatient with ceftriaxone IM, doxycycline bid/14days and reexamine in 10days.
Hospitalization with cefoxitin IV and doxycycline oral twice daily for 14days.
Hospitalization with ceftriaxone IM single dose, doxycycline oral for 14days.

questions.stem: PID is characterized by all the following EXCEPT:

A 26-year-old female presents with dull aches in lower abdomen and pelvis for 2weeks. There is no discharge. She had multiple sexual partners and does not use condoms. BP: 110/65, pulse: 80/min, temp: 38.5. On PV there is tenderness on moving cx but no masses. Pregnancy test is positive. Best next step is:
options: Treat her with penicillin as outpatient.
Admit the patient and treat with levofloxacin and doxycycline.
Admit her and treat her with IV cefoxitin and oral azithromycin.
Treat her with IM ceftriaxone and azithromycin as outpatient.

questions.stem: A sexually active woman presents with dysuria and vaginal discharge. All the following may be the cause EXCEPT:

During laparoscopy for an infertile woman, thin filmy adhesions are presents around the fallopian tubes and also on the undersurface of the liver. her past history is irrelevant.
A 25-year-old P1+0., presents in the post menstrual period with offensive vaginal discharge and marked lower abdominal pain with fever.
An infertile woman with bilateral tubal block had been counseled for tubal disconnection before ICSI procedure to improve the outcome. what is the suggested pathology she has?
Localized tenderness, rebound tenderness and guarding with temperature 38.5
Painless serpiginous ulcers associated with mucocutaneous rash.
Contact bleeding and mucopurulent discharge with temperature 37.2
Associated with microscopic motile trophozoites and vaginal ph>4.5.
A sexually transmitted disease characterized by painful vesicles and genital ulcers.

Itchy white vaginal discharge with vaginal ph<4.5.
A non-sexually transmitted infection which is itchy, white curdy with sore vagina.
Causative organism that may cause silent upper genital tract infection.
Specifically targeted by national vaccination program, with vaccine given to girls aged 12-13yrs.
The treatment should include intravaginal estrogen therapy.
Associated with vaginal ph>4.5, clue cells and fishy amine odor.
A non-sexually transmitted disease characterized with offensive fishy discharge.
Most common type of vaginitis with a high Ph in the sexually active mature patient.
A sexually transmitted disease characterized by Gram-negative diplococcic and colonizing columnar and transitional epithelium.
Diagnosis may require vaginoscopy.
A 22-year-old, pregnant 32 weeks with whitish curdy itchy vaginal discharge.
options: Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days.
Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old with purulent vaginal discharge, temp 37.8 and mild lower abdominal pain.
options: Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days.
Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old with IUD in situ, backache, mucopurulent discharge and contact bleeding.
options: Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days.
Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: A 37-year-old with yellowish frothy excessive malodorous discharge and normal cervix on speculum examination.
options: Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days.
Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: A 16-year-old virgin with cottage cheese vulval discharge.
options: Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 7 days.
Oral Doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 14 days.

questions.stem: Treatment for syphilis in pregnancy that prevents 98% of congenital infections.
Treatment of chlamydia infection during pregnancy.
Treatment for 1ry genital herpes infection in pregnancy.
Treatment of acute cervicitis in non-pregnant 24 years old female.
A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman is recently remarried and has superficial dyspareunia.
A 52-year-old postmenopausal woman complains of intense itching around her vagina and anus makes intercourse and defecate painful.
A 45-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes reports that she has tears on her vagina causing pain with intercourse and defecation.

A 54-year-old postmenopausal woman complains of itching in her vagina and the physician notices scaly lesions on both of her elbows.
Lichen sclerosis may cause pruritis vulvae.
Chancroid may cause benign vulval ulcer.
HPV infection may cause benign vulval ulcer.
Tertiary syphilis may cause benign vulval ulcer.
Vaginal pH is increased under the influence of estrogen.
Candida infection is increased in pregnancy, with COCPs usage and broad-spectrum antibiotic usage.
Neisseria gonorrhea has affinity to transitional epithelium, hence the occurrence of Bartholinitis.
Urine retention and perineal pain are common presentations of HSV.
The causative organism of 1ry syphilis is treponema pallidum.
1ry infection of syphilis usually presents with a painful ulcer on the perineum.
1ry and 2ry syphilis are not life threatening, however, 3ry neurosyphilis is life threatening, hence the importance of making the diagnosis.
The commonest pathology detected in laparoscopy for chronic pelvic pain is endometriosis.
Treatment of choice in treatment of syphilis is penicillin.
Doxycycline can be safely given during pregnancy.
Oral fluconazole as treatment of candidiasis is contraindicated in pregnancy.
In case of TB of female genital tract, the fallopian tubes are affected in 100% of cases.
Chlamydia infection can cause Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome.
Condyloma accuminata is considered a precancerous lesion.
Incubation period for HIV is around 3-6months.
Bartholin cyst is best treated by marsupialization.
